name: Concord Academy
description:
Concord Academy is a coeducational, independent, college preparatory school for grades nine through twelve, located in historic Concord, Massachusetts.

Mission Statement

We are a community animated by love of learning,
diverse and striving for equity,
with common trust as our foundation.

Honoring each individual, we challenge and expand
our understanding of ourselves and the world
through purposeful collaboration and creative engagement.

We cultivate empathy, integrity, and responsibility
to build a more just and sustainable future.

This spring, CA‚Äôs Community and Equity Office launched Strive, a powerful student-led workshop series designed to foster cultural understanding through shared stories and interactive learning. From exploring identity and privilege to celebrating traditions like henna art and hair culture, the sessions invited participants to engage deeply with lived experiences beyond their own. With strong student turnout and plans to expand next year, Strive is becoming a meaningful new CA staple. Learn more: bit.ly/3FFJnaZ

Nicholas Brown, our talented clarinet teacher at Concord Academy, was recently featured in The Boston Globe for his work with the Boston Festival Orchestra (BFO)! Co-founding the BFO with violinist Alyssa Wang in 2019, Nick has been a driving force in bringing classical music to new audiences. His leadership as both the Executive Director and Principal Clarinetist is helping to shape the future of music in Boston. We‚Äôre incredibly proud to have him as part of our faculty. Read more: bit.ly/43PZs7d

Photo credit: Pat Greenhouse

As we reflect on the moments that made this year‚Äôs Commencement special, one experience that truly resonated with students was Barbershop hosted by the Head of School‚Äôs Office on May 29. In the days leading up to graduation, talented barbers from MOBAR Barbershop came to campus, offering professional haircuts and meaningful conversation in a relaxed, welcoming space. The following day, our graduates crossed the stage looking and feeling their best.

Photo credit: Samuel Williams

Please join us in welcoming the newest members of CA‚Äôs Alum Association! In late May, our seniors were officially inducted over a joyful breakfast celebration. They heard inspiring speeches from Carly Egan, Assistant Director of the Annual Fund, and Shreya Patel ‚Äô21, a member of the CA Young Alum Community Committee, who shared how she stays connected and encouraged others to get involved too. The morning wrapped up with a few rounds of CA-themed bingo, and each senior received a special gift from the Alum Association. Congratulations to the class of 2025!

More than 200 Concord Academy alums returned to campus for Reunion and Alum Weekend in early June, celebrating lifelong connections and the school‚Äôs enduring spirit. From thought-provoking panels and historic tours to joyful gatherings in the new Centennial Arts Center, the weekend honored CA‚Äôs legacy while looking boldly to the future. Read the event recap and view photos from the special weekend: bit.ly/4kNjHbJ

The show was the very first to be presented in the new Centennial Arts Center. Relive the highlights by exploring the photo gallery from the special showcase: bit.ly/3Td4gx8

What an unforgettable Reunion and Alum Weekend! Thank you to everyone who came to Concord Academy to celebrate, reconnect, and make lasting memories. Your presence made this weekend truly special. We can‚Äôt wait to welcome you back again soon.

With performances across the U.S. and abroad, Potts reflects on her passion for creativity and equity rooted in her time at Concord Academy. Learn more from CA News: bit.ly/3JvehUW

We‚Äôre thrilled to share the cover story for the latest issue of the New England Real Estate Journal, featuring the incredible Centennial Arts Center (C.A.C.) at Concord Academy! The 37,000 square-foot facility, designed in collaboration with DSK | Dewing Schmid Kearns Architects + Planners and Windover Construction, is transforming our student experience with sustainable design, cutting-edge technology, and innovative spaces. From its 175-seat theater to its digital production lab, the C.A.C. is not only a hub for performance but a dynamic learning environment. Check out the full story: bit.ly/41cAbSM

On Friday, May 30, Concord Academy celebrated the Class of 2025 with a joyful Commencement ceremony. The event honored each graduate‚Äôs unique journey, highlighted by a moving speech from beloved educator Max Hall, who retired in 2024 after 21 years at CA. Drawing on the spirit of our mascot, the Chameleon, Hall encouraged graduates to embrace change and resilience. ‚ÄúCA keeps inviting us to grow,‚Äù he shared. We invite you to relive this momentous day through a photo gallery, recap story, and video:  bit.ly/45bilTa

CA Athletics enjoyed another successful season, including Eastern Independent League (EIL) titles, New England Preparatory School Athletic Council (NEPSAC) championship bids, and a victory over Bancroft School in the fourth annual Spring Cup rivalry event. Student athletes demonstrated Concord Academy‚Äôs values of teamwork, good sportsmanship, and competitive grit. Relive the highlights in a season recap: bit.ly/44ZgSPz

Today, we celebrated the incredible Class of 2025 at Concord Academy‚Äôs Commencement. From the inspiring words of our Commencement speaker to the joyful moment each senior received their diploma, it was a powerful tribute to resilience, growth, and achievement. Congratulations to our remarkable graduates. Your future starts now!

A toast to a great legacy! With joy and deep appreciation, we recently gathered for ‚ÄúA Toast to the Centennial Arts Center,‚Äù when it was announced that the C.A.C. support shop will be named in honor of Director of Campus Planning, Design, and Construction Don Kingman. For 31 years, Don has been a steadfast presence at CA. True to our mission and values, it is our people who make CA the special place that it is, as Don‚Äôs commitment beautifully illustrates. Don, we honor your years of service and wish you a happy retirement. As the sign in front of the support shop reads, ‚ÄúBecause you cared, CA thrived.‚Äù

The Diversity Dinner on April 26 was a night to remember. Hosted by the Leaders of Color Coalition, the program brought together current CA students and alums for an open conversation about how we can continue building a more inclusive, student-centered Concord Academy. We were honored to be joined by Karen McAlmon ‚Äô75, a current board member, and Lara Jordan James ‚Äô80, a former board member and alum panelist at this year‚Äôs Reunion. Their shared insights across generations inspired everyone in the room.

Photography by Rodolfo Wang ‚Äô26

On April 19, Concord celebrated the 250th anniversary of the Battles of Concord and Lexington with over 70,000 attendees! In the lead-up to this historic event, CA celebrated the spirit of the Revolution with hands-on learning initiatives like an essay contest, immersive art exhibitions, and an augmented reality tour.  A special shoutout to Rob Munro, CA‚Äôs Assistant Head for the Academic Program and Equity, and co-chair of the Concord250 Executive Committee, for helping bring this incredible experience to life. Learn more: bit.ly/435Aor3 #Concord250

Concord Academy‚Äôs Centennial Arts Center is more than a creative hub‚Äîit‚Äôs a model of sustainable design. Fully electric, with solar panels and smart systems, it‚Äôs shaping a greener campus. Learn more: bit.ly/3Gomj05

On Monday, we proudly celebrated the 2025 recipients of the Joan Shaw Herman Award for Distinguished Service: Leslie Taylor Davol ‚Äô87 and Sam Davol ‚Äô88. The event featured a lively presentation, a question and answer session, and a pop-up display highlighting their nonprofit, Street Lab, which brings reading and learning opportunities to public spaces across New York City. Learn more: bit.ly/42HcUd1

Last Friday, CA spring teams combined for five wins to once again secure the Spring Cup in the annual rivalry event with the Bancroft School. Congrats to the teams and thanks to the Bancroft community for hosting. Go Green!

GRiT 2025 was out of this world! On April 12, CA students soared into space, science, and AI at the 5th annual Gender Representation in Technology on-campus conference. A huge shoutout to the incredible speakers‚ÄîLaura Brenneman P‚Äô28, Isabelle Lussier, Pilar Verhaak, and Kelsie Lopez‚Äîand all the attendees who made it unforgettable.

The on-campus All Community Campaign for the Annual Fund (ACC) is underway. Between now and May 2, our faculty, staff, and students are invited to come together in support of CA‚Äôs Annual Fund. Students can show their support by making a gift to the Annual Fund, pledging to support the Annual Fund in the future, or writing a thank you note to a CA donor. On Wednesday, students gathered for the first ACC Thankathon and wrote 111 thank-you notes. Make your gift to the Annual Fund at concordacademy.org/give.

Today marks the 250th anniversary of the Battles of Lexington and Concord that ignited the American Revolution. To honor the milestone, Kim Frederick‚Äîa Concord Academy history teacher and member of the Concord250 civic engagement committee‚Äîis bringing history to life with ‚ÄúRevolutionary Trunks.‚Äù These hands-on kits for students in grades 3‚Äì7 across Massachusetts are filled with artifacts and hands-on, inclusive lesson plans. Learn more: bit.ly/42A0NwZ

On April 3, Concord Academy‚Äôs Modern and Classical Languages Department Head Carmen Welton and student Evan Griffith-Ebrahimi ‚Äô26 presented at the New England Association of Schools and Colleges (NEASC) Educator Showcase in Nashua, N.H. Their session, ‚ÄúSelf-Pacing in the Modern Classroom,‚Äù explored how autonomous learning can empower students and accommodate different learning styles. Learn more about the presentation: bit.ly/3Gcb3Uy

We are thrilled to announce this year‚Äôs recipients of the Concord Academy Joan Shaw Herman Award for Distinguished Service, Leslie Taylor Davol ‚Äô87 and Sam Davol ‚Äô88. This honor is presented annually to members of the CA community who embody a commitment to service. Nearly 20 years ago, Leslie and Sam had an idea to give at-risk youth an opportunity to read right where they already gather. Today, their pop-up reading room efforts to strengthen neighborhoods have grown into their nonprofit Street Lab, deploying 15+ types of pop-up programs 500+ times a year across New York City. They also ship kits around the world for other cities to do similar work. Learn more: bit.ly/3Ri0ZMh

Check out more photos here: bit.ly/4l93AFZ. Interested in helping plan future CAYAC gatherings? Contact Carly Egan in the CA Advancement and Engagement Office: carly_egan@concordacademy.org

Congratulations to CA alum Josh Duboff ‚Äô04 on his debut novel, Early Thirties, publishing next week with Simon & Schuster! The book follows two best friends‚Äô search for connection and love in New York. Josh‚Äôs book is already making waves with rave reviews from Marie Claire, Time, Bustle, and Town & Country, among others. Josh will be at the Harvard Bookstore in Cambridge on Tuesday, March 25, at 7:00 p.m. for a special book event. CA community members are invited to stop by and join the fun. On January 28, Harvard Book Store hosted an event at The Brattle Theater honoring Imani Perry ‚Äô90, a National Book Award winner, CA trustee, and Harvard professor. Perry discussed her new book, Black in Blues, which explores the cultural significance of the color blue in Black history. The work intertwines the author‚Äôs personal stories with in-depth historical research. Learn more: bit.ly/4hMNijo

The Washington Post journalist and author Ben Terris ‚Äô04 credits his success to engaging with people of diverse perspectives. In a conversation with CA junior Jacob Himelfarb ‚Äô26, he reflects on how his CA experience shaped his approach to navigating difficult conversations, highlighting the value of listening and considering all viewpoints. Learn more: bit.ly/40SD61Y üì∞

As the new semester begins, construction at the Centennial Arts Center is quickly advancing toward completion in early spring. Over the next few weeks, the primary focus will be on interior finishes, with millwork, painting, and installation of theater seating underway. In alignment with our sustainability goals, a solar array on the theater roof, native landscaping, and a pollinator meadow have been integrated into the project along with no fossil fuels used for heating or cooling. When finalized in spring 2025, this environmentally friendly space will enhance the school‚Äôs vision for creative collaboration and unify the east and west sides of the campus.

Hey D.C. alums! Join us on January 26, 2025, for a special private tour of the National Portrait Gallery followed by brunch. It‚Äôs a special opportunity to reconnect with fellow CA grads, enjoy some art, and catch up over good food. Spouses and partners are welcome too. We hope to see you there. RSVP by January 18: bit.ly/3DL9s72

As we dance into the new year, let's look back at 2024's most inspiring moments. From classroom experiences to campus events, the past year has been all about community. Relive the highlights in the latest CA News article: bit.ly/3VLQrrf

Here's to even more amazing memories in the year ahead! üéâ

Last Thursday, students in Kim Frederick's Ottoman Empire course turned history into art, presenting sculptural ottomans that reflected on topics in Ottoman culture. This creative assignment fused research with hands-on craftsmanship.  Frederick shared, ‚ÄúI aspire to design multi-modal work for students, where authorship and historical imagination lead to deep learning and rigorous engagement with the material.‚Äù

On December 4, NPR White House correspondent Asma Khalid spoke at CA on the theme of courageous conflict engagement and resolution. Examining how media consumption in the U.S. has become increasingly polarized over the past decade, she upheld the value in listening to others with different perspectives and political opinions. Learn more: bit.ly/49nm7J9

As CA‚Äôs West Campus construction project continues, the Centennial Arts Center is taking shape. The building exterior is complete and interior finishes will be a focus for the next three months. Landscaping work will complement the project with new trees and plantings framing the building. Once finalized, the revitalized Academy Garden will expand from a quarter-acre to almost a half-acre. This aerial photo taken from the late 1950s/early 1960s alongside a current view, highlights how much our campus has grown.

Concord Academy educators are sparking a revolution in learning! In celebration of the 250th anniversary of the American Revolution, Concord Museum has partnered with CA history teachers Kim Frederick and Topi Dasgupta P'22 '25 to create traveling classroom trunks filled with replicas of historical artifacts. These hands-on learning experiences go beyond the textbook, allowing students to engage with the past in exciting new ways. Learn more from The Concord Bridge: bit.ly/40Zsznf

#Concord250 #CollaborativeLearning #HandsOnHistory

Last Friday, CA welcomed guest speaker Aaron Golub, the first legally blind athlete to play football in a Division 1 game. His interactive assembly involved students in an exercise in thinking differently, and through sharing his life story, he encouraged a shift in perspective on how we face obstacles and what they can teach us. Learn more: https://lnkd.in/esTTvWhA

As we get closer to December 31, it‚Äôs a great time to consider your year-end giving to CA!

Your support to CA through your Donor Advised Fund (DAF), foundations, or appreciated assets like stocks, bonds, or mutual funds will have an immediate impact on the student experience. Please keep in mind that mutual fund calendar-year end-gifts to CA may take up to 30 days to process with our broker. For more information on ways to give, please visit: https://lnkd.in/etXYBNFm.

State Representative Simon Cataldo visited CA history teacher Kim Frederick‚Äôs American Suburbs U.S. history class last week. He‚Äôs one of several local public figures to connect with her students this semester to offer perspectives on the affordability crisis here in Concord, Mass., and the complex process underway to explore the development of the recently decommissioned MCI-Concord prison. As the class learns about the history of suburbanization, they‚Äôre hearing from some of the individuals contributing to a new state-local partnership model.

In Partnership with The Boys' Club of New York and Inspiring Young Minds, Concord Academy and the Groton School hosted Lunch and Learn: The Boarding School Advantage at the Gerry Clubhouse in East Harlem this past weekend. Designed to offer guidance and support, families heard from a panel of alums and admissions officers, developing their interest and knowledge of Concord, Groton, and boarding schools as a whole. CA alum Lewis Salas '09 joined Melody Rosas-Granda, Coordinator of Multicultural Outreach and Associate Director of Admission, to share his experience as a boarding student at CA. Thank you to the Boys' Club of New York's Director of Educational and Career Services, Antonio Aponte, and the President and Co-Founder of Inspiring Young Minds, Mark Cheong,  for hosting CA alongside Groton Admissions.
